>  I am sorry now that I got involved in this testing, this is not a science
> class, and I am sorry list members, I was unaware of what they were up to.
> no wonder David (the tech) did not want to get involved.  We don't know
> who people are on these lists to begin with, and I should have been more
> careful, getting old.  sf
>
>  In a message dated 7/11/2010 11:37:38 A.M. Eastern Daylight Time,
> rasterer@yahoo. com writes:
>
>
>
>   Your points are well taken John.  And I agree it is a first attempt and
> certainly can be improved on successive trials, and cannot determine the
> origin of the messages.
>
> For this first experiment/protocol , I thought we would go as generic as
> possible: it doesn't matter really here where the information comes from, or
> how different people interpret it: just determine the object in the specific
> timeframe.  We'll start with data on how accurate the participants can get,
> however they do it.
>
> As to your comment on the audio files:  originally I considered requiring
> as part of the protocol to include the audio.  Maybe that is still a good
> idea.  The reason I didn't, is because people often claim to hear different
> things each time they listen to a file.  Posting a file with an incorrect
> answer, for example, the person may later claim (after the experiment) to
> NOW hear the right answer.  And others may confirm it.
>
> This seemed liked a rabbit hole, and I'm not sure how to handle it. So for
> this trial, I figured we'd just not go there, and require replies only be
> valid if they are given during the experiments specified time frame. Once
> the actual object is know, it seems too easy for a person to come up with
> the answer.
>
> But yeah, we need to see how this goes, fix the problems, and come up with
> more of them!
>
> --- On *Sun, 7/11/10, John S <phenom_investigator @yahoo.com>* wrote:
>
>
> From: John S <phenom_investigator @...>
> Subject: [EVP-ITC] Improved protocol
>
> To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups .com
> Date: Sunday, July 11, 2010, 8:08 AM
>
>
>
>  Since we're talking about experiments and protocols here are some ideas
> to improve
> the protocol RJ suggested initially. Using a test target is one way of
> establishing a
> truth in time, which is the basis of this experiment. But there are a
> couple of issues.
>
> It is quite possible that someone could discern the target through remote
> viewing alone.
> This would negate the need for involvement of a spirit communicator or
> discarnate entity.
> Outcomes depend on the word of those reporting. The true skeptic (not
> cynic) would
> therefore say that this experiment contains a basic flaw in that it does
> not uniquely
> indicate that the information was obtained in the prescribed manner.
> Providing access
> to the raw audio file would not necessarily constitute proof either, since
> many of these
> communications can only be heard by certain people,
>
> If the audio file were quite clear, timing  becomes an issue. In other
> words, when was
> the audio actually recorded?  This issue can be mitigated simply by
> requiring any
> claimant to email the audio file to a trusted party before the test ends.
> It would be best
> if the trusted party were not otherwise involved in the experiment and it
> was  their duty
> simply to collect the claims. Once all claims had been collected they could
> be posted
> publicly for review by the community in general.  The experimenter could
> decide if any
> of the claims seemed to have hit, and this decision could be reviewed by
> anyone if desired.
>
> The important detail however is that this experiment does not completely
> answer the
> question. It is a first attempt and certainly can be improved on successive
> trials.
>
> Successive trials are always a good idea, since it provides replication.
> And it would be
> best if others replicated the experiment using a very similar protocol. If
> these were to
> succeed, the community could then state that out of X trials Y had
> succeeded (by
> some definition of success) potentially giving a success rate above that
> expected
> by random chance. This would make the outcome quantifiable and measureable
> and thus meaningful.
>
> But also important to note, this would only prove the potential veracity of
> the messages.
> It would not (and cannot as far as I can tell) prove the origin of the
> messages. This detail
> will, I fear, remain a matter for belief and speculation for quite some
> time to come.
>
>
>
>
>
>
>  
>
